p.s: The protagonists in the given exerptexcerpt from The Merchant of Venice by William Shakespeare are Shylock and his friend Tubal.
In the following Shylock will be characterized by looking at the use of language.
Shylock is portrayed as a greedy character.

When Tubal tells him that he was not able to find Shylock's daughter, Shylock immediately mains for his stolen jewels and for the money he will have to pay for the search (ll. 3-7), instead of his daughter.
Shakespeare uses two repetitions in line 3 and in line 5 to portray this character trait.
Twice Shylock repeats that he wishes his daughter was dead (ll. 5-6), showing how vengeful he is.
A rhetorical question in l. 7 makes clear how frustrated he is.
The fact that Shylock wants Jessica dead and that he describes her as a thief (l. 8) shows how hurt Shylock is because his own daughter stole from him and ran away with a Christian.
An anaphora in line 8 to 10 presents Shylock as pessimistic and bitter.
Shakespeare uses repititionsrepetitions frequently.
afterAfterShylock hears that Antonio will be late, to show how excited Shylock is about this information (ll. 12, 14, 16).
Shylock appears to be gleeful.
This character trait is also created by the use of an exclamation in line 16.
The metaphor thou stickest a dagger in me (l. 18) makes clear that money is more important to Shylock than his daughter.
Even though this makes him seem cold-hearted, he is not only greedy.
This becomes obvious when Shylock hears about the lost ring of his dead wife and says I would not have given it for a wilderness of monkeys (l. 25), showing how hurt he is.
Shylock appears to be not only vengeful but also merciless when explaining that he will plague and torture Antonio (l. 22).
Shylock is very religious, which becomes clear when he thanks god for Antonio's ship that has cast away (l. 14) and when he tells his jewishJewish friend to meet him at their synagogue (l. 29-30).
Shylock dominates the conversation presenting him as straight-forward and confident.
He speaks prose, which generally lower class citizens were speaking.
This is supposed to make it easier for the audience to notice how greedy he is.
In conclusion Shylock is portrayed as greedy, vengeful, gleeful but also as hurta nd bitter.
These character traits are created through the use of language, especially repititionsrepetitions and metaphors.
